comment: Avar nus 'hundred' originates in the word nus 'knife' [saidova2008: 267].

example_comment: -na is -da assimilated to the final /n/ in bešan

comment: This root in Hunzib and Bezhta is different than in other Tsezic languages. It has the meaning 'knife' just like the Avar word for 'hundred', nus [comrieetal2015: 561]. It has possibly appeared as a result of borrowing of this semantic shift from Avar. The obligatory use of hə̃s 'one' before 'hundred' indicates the same (this happens with loanwords).

This root in Hunzib and Bezhta is different than in other Tsezic languages. It has the meaning 'knife' just like the Avar word for 'hundred', nus [comrieetal2015: 561]. It has possibly appeared as a result of borrowing of this semantic shift from Avar. The obligatory use of hə̃s 'one' before 'hundred' indicates the same (this happens with loanwords).
[starostin: 435] gives a more merged form: fəq:a-d.
[desheriev1953: 189] also mentions the root /as/ 'hundred', borrowed from Georgian. According to this source, the native vigesimal derivation is mostly forgotten now and not replicated by youth.
